knowledge: Angina Angina  Angina is a type of chest pain that occurs when there is not enough blood flow to the heart.  It is a symptom of coronary artery disease, which occurs when the blood vessels that supply the heart become narrow or blocked.  Angina is usually described as a pressure or squeezing sensation in the chest that may spread to the arms, neck, jaw, shoulder or back.  It may also be accompanied by shortness of breath, sweating, nausea or dizziness.  Treatment for angina includes lifestyle changes, medications and procedures such as angioplasty or bypass surgery. Angina Angina
response: The risk factors for angina include smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, family history of heart disease, sedentary lifestyle, obesity, and diabetes.

knowledge: Arrhythmia Arrhythmia Although the goal of drug therapy is to prevent arrhythmia, nearly every antiarrhythmic drug has the potential to act as a pro-arrhythmic, and so must be carefully selected and used under medical supervision. Several groups of drugs slow conduction through the heart, without actually preventing an arrhythmia. These drugs can be used to 'rate control' a fast rhythm and make it physically tolerable for the patient. Some arrhythmias promote blood clotting within the heart and increase the risk of embolus and stroke. Anticoagulant medications such as warfarin and heparins, and anti-platelet drugs such as aspirin can reduce the risk of clotting. Arrhythmias may also be treated electrically, by applying a shock across the heart – either externally to the chest wall, or internally to the heart via implanted electrodes. response: I recommend seeing a doctor right away to get a diagnosis and proper treatment for arrhythmia.
